description:
Phacochoerus africanus, commonly known as the common warthog or African warthog, is a species of wild pig native to sub-Saharan Africa. It is a member of the Suidae family and is one of the most recognizable and distinctive species of pigs.

The warthog is characterized by its large, rounded head, prominent warts on the face, and a long, sloping back that gives it a distinctive appearance. It has a stocky build, short legs, and a coarse, bristly coat that ranges in color from brown to black. The most notable feature of the warthog is its pair of curved, protruding tusks, which can grow up to 60 cm (24 inches) in length.

Warthogs are primarily grazers and browsers, feeding on a variety of grasses, herbs, roots, and occasionally small animals. They are known for their social behavior, often living in close-knit family groups called sounders, which can consist of several adult females and their offspring.

The warthog is adapted to the harsh, dry environments of sub-Saharan Africa, with the ability to withstand high temperatures and limited water availability. It plays an important role in the ecosystem, serving as a food source for predators and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the region.
